tweet: On October 31, 2008 Satoshi Nakamoto released a white paper to the world, and almost nobody cared. People thought that global, decentralized money with no one in control was insane.  10 years on, we're proving them wrong day by day. Here's to the next decade & beyond. #bitcoin 🥂

#IOST CEO @jimmyzhong_iost shared his view on 10 years of #Bitcoin with @newsbtc:  "The future is bright for #blockchain because the core of engineers and dreamers continue to grow, improving tech and pushing the boundaries of what can be accomplished!"   https://t.co/Y7oKQ17BPS
Bitcoin is 10 years old and feels incredibly young.  Facebook is 14 years old and feels incredibly old.

A decade ago, Satoshi Nakamoto published "Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System" and set us on the path to do for money what the shipping container did for goods and the Internet did for data -- enabling us to create a truly interconnected global economy.

Yes, Bitcoin reached $100B and worldwide recognition in its first 10 years on its way to becoming digital gold. And yes it now commands the respect of millions, and yes it has disappointed all who pronounced it dead, and yes it has just been glorious. But the best is yet to come.

According to digiconomist, the average carbon footprint of a single Bitcoin transaction is around 396.92kg of CO2.  That's like burning 46 gallons of gasoline when you want to pay a friend for dinner.

@Daeinar @veorq @nature That paper completely misunderstands how bitcoin scales: it assumes that the energy usage of PoW grows linearly with the number of transactions, which simply isn't true. PoW is an overhead that's mostly fixed regardless of how many transactions are done, not a marginal cost.
